• The study investigates spin-superflow turbulence (sst) in a spin-1 ferromagnetic spinor Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC), revealing that both the superflow kinetic energy and the spin-dependent interaction energy exhibit Kolmogorov and @xmath1 power laws, respectively.
• Theoretical considerations suggest that the Kolmogorov spectrum in sst arises from the nonlinear spin term, differing from classical turbulence (ct) where it originates from the inertial term.
• Numerical simulations confirm the presence of the Kolmogorov and @xmath1 power laws in the energy spectra of sst, with the Kolmogorov spectrum sustained by the nonlinear spin term and the @xmath1 power law by the spin-dependent interaction energy flux.
• The study also explores the possibility of an inverse energy cascade in sst, noting that while the superflow kinetic energy shows a Kolmogorov spectrum, the spin-dependent interaction energy may exhibit an inverse cascade, although the direction of energy cascade for the spin-dependent interaction energy is not yet fully understood.

• The study investigates the kondo lattice model (klm) on a square lattice, focusing on the ground state and the evolution of the fermi surface topology across magnetic transitions using dynamical cluster approximation (dca) and quantum monte carlo (qmc) simulations.
• The results show no kondo breakdown throughout the phase diagram, even in the antiferromagnetic ordered state, with the heavy quasi-particle gap interpreted in terms of kondo screening.
• The transition from the paramagnetic to the antiferromagnetic state is continuous, associated with the backfolding of the large fermi surface, and within the antiferromagnetic phase, there is a fermi surface topology change from hole pockets centered around @xmath0 to those centered around @xmath1.
• The transition in the fermi surface topology corresponds to two continuous lifshitz transitions, with the volume of the hole pockets remaining constant due to the luttinger sum rule. The absence of kondo breakdown is confirmed by the single-particle spectral function.

* The discovery of pulsations in two extremely low-mass white dwarfs (wd), sdss j161431.28 + 191219.4 and sdss j222859.93 + 362359.6, extends the known range of pulsating white dwarfs to cooler temperatures and lower surface gravities than previously observed.
* These findings challenge the notion of a pure instability strip for he-core white dwarfs and suggest that not all elm wd's will necessarily pass through the instability strip in the same manner as co-core zz Ceti stars, potentially complicating the evolutionary models of these objects.
* Theoretical predictions for the blue edge of the instability strip are more reliable than for the red edge, and the newly discovered pulsating elm wds provide an opportunity to test these predictions and further explore the physics of white dwarf pulsations at cooler temperatures.

* The vertical extension to the red clump in the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC), previously interpreted as a foreground stellar population, is argued to originate from the LMC itself, consistent with stellar evolutionary models. This conclusion is based on the presence of the feature in all LMC fields, its precise agreement with the blue loops of intermediate-mass core helium-burning stars, and its relative stellar density being consistent with a salpeter initial mass function (IMF) and continuous star formation over the last 1 billion years in the LMC.
* The same stellar evolutionary models predict the vertical extension in the Hipparcos color-magnitude diagram (cmd) of the solar neighborhood, suggesting that the LMC's red clump features are not unique and can be explained by stellar evolution without invoking a separate foreground population.

• The study applies radiative and chemical post-processing to large-scale galactic disk simulations to compute the equilibrium chemical and thermal state of the disk, focusing on the molecular content of hydrogen and carbon monoxide (H2 and CO) and the effects of radiative shielding by dust and molecules. The simulations reveal that significant concentrations of H2 are vertically restricted to within 200 pc of the galactic midplane and possess a filamentary morphology, while CO is found in the highest density clumps, interior to H2-rich gas. Radiative shielding is crucial for the development of molecular gas, with self-shielding being dominant for H2 and regime-dependent for CO. The study compares various local approximations for radiative shielding to ray-tracing based solutions, finding that the six-ray approximation, temperature-capped jeans length, and power-law fit perform the best in matching the H2 and CO abundances of the fiducial model. The temperature-capped jeans length is recommended for use as a proxy for radiative shielding length in multidimensional simulations.

• The study presents a fast and efficient method, termed the frozen nucleon approximation, for calculating inclusive two-particle-two-hole (2p-2h) responses in the relativistic fermi gas model, reducing the computational complexity from seven nested integrals to a single integral.
• The validity of the frozen approximation is confirmed through comparison with exact calculations, demonstrating its effectiveness for a range of momentum transfers relevant to neutrino oscillation experiments.

• The paper presents the first monitoring observations of the low luminosity active galactic nucleus ( AGN) h 0507 + 164, spanning about one month, to estimate the black hole mass using reverberation mapping. The observed frame time lag between the h@xmath2 emission line flux and the continuum flux at 5100   was found to be approximately @xmath61 days, which corresponds to a black hole mass of @xmath75 m@xmath5 in the rest frame of the source.
• The estimated time lag and black hole mass are in agreement with the known @xmath11l@xmath12@xmath13l@xmath14  relationship, suggesting a continuation of this relation to lower luminosities.

• The study investigates the relationship between star formation in galaxy clusters and cluster properties such as mass and radius, using data from the Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer (WISE) and the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS). It focuses on obscured star-forming galaxies (demi-LIRGs) in 69 local galaxy clusters at redshift @xmath0.

• The research finds that the mean specific star formation rate (mssfr) increases with projected distance from the cluster center but remains below the field value even at 3 times the cluster virial radius. The fraction of demi-LIRGs also increases with radius but is suppressed at large radii, suggesting that star formation may be quenched in galaxies that have previously resided in less dense environments.

• The study concludes that there is no significant correlation between the total cluster star formation rate (cssfr) and cluster mass, indicating that cluster mechanisms like ram pressure or harassment, which scale with cluster mass, do not play a dominant role in the evolution of star formation in local clusters.

• The results suggest that strangulation, a process where a galaxy's cold gas supply is cut off as it enters the intracluster medium, may be a dominant mechanism for quenching star formation in galaxy clusters, regardless of their mass. This process could be efficient in small groups or filaments as well.

* The recent discovery of the Higgs boson at the LHC has implications for understanding particle mass and its potential role in gravity and cosmology.
* Nonminimal coupling between the Higgs field and spacetime curvature could explain inflation and dark energy contributions, with bounds on such couplings derived from LHC experiments.
* White dwarfs, with their stable spectra, offer a controlled environment to search for Higgs-curvature coupling effects, specifically through the Kretschmann invariant.
* The study focuses on carbon-rich white dwarfs, using spectroscopic observations to detect potential wavelength shifts in electronic transitions versus molecular transitions.
* The white dwarf bpm 27606, with known proper motion and distance, provides a benchmark for testing the Higgs-curvature coupling effect.
* The absence of shifts between vibrational and electronic transitions in the swan bands suggests upper bounds on the Higgs-Kretschmann coupling.
* Procyon b, another white dwarf with both atomic and molecular features, also shows no relative shifts between electronic and vibrational transitions, supporting the absence of Higgs-curvature coupling.
* The analysis provides upper bounds on the Higgs-Kreschmann coupling, which are significantly more stringent than those from LHC experiments.
* The methodology is complementary to LHC bounds and can be applied to other scalar fields, potentially offering even more stringent constraints.
* Future improvements include better measurements of pressure shifts and a detailed spectral energy distribution analysis.
* The study suggests that white dwarfs could be valuable astrophysical laboratories for testing the Higgs field's interaction with spacetime curvature.
* The research was supported by various institutions and used data from the Southern African Large Telescope and the Hubble Space Telescope.

• The study proposes three methods to measure the dust extinction law slope ( @xmath0) in the direction of differentially-reddened galactic globular clusters, using three-band optical photometry.
• The methods rely on the premise that the width of the blue horizontal branch (hb) is minimized when the correct @xmath0 value is used to correct for extinction and reddening.
• Simulated cluster data sets are used to estimate the accuracy of each method, with varying levels of photometric error and @xmath0 values.
• The "@"xmath25 rms" and "@"xmath25 slope" methods can determine @xmath0 to an accuracy of @xmath1 for clusters with low photometric error (@xmath1550.3 mag).
• The "optical/ir" method generally provides less precise estimates of @xmath0 across all photometric error levels.
• Combining results from all three methods gives a mean extinction law slope of @xmath7 for the direction of the low-latitude galactic globular cluster NGC 4833.
• The scatter in the hb of NGC 4833 is used to estimate the amount of small-scale structure in the dust complex in the foreground of the cluster.
• The angular power spectrum of dust fluctuations in the direction of NGC 4833 is derived from the cluster's relative visual extinction data, matching smoothly onto the larger-scale power spectrum from the Schlegel et al. (1998) map.
• The overall power spectrum is well-fitted by a power law with an index of @xmath14, indicating the fraction of power missed by the Schlegel et al. (1998) map on small scales relative to larger scales.
• The study suggests that the methods presented can be applied to various star clusters and multi-band data sets to probe the nature of dust along many lines of sight.
• The authors acknowledge the contributions of colleagues and the availability of NGC 4833 observations for this study.

• The paper investigates the strong Bishop-Phelps-Bollobs property (sbpbp) for bounded linear operators, focusing on conditions under which pairs of Banach spaces satisfy this property. It introduces the sbpbp for operators, which requires that given a Banach space @xmath0 and a compact operator @xmath1, there exists a vector in @xmath0 such that the operator attains its norm at this vector.

• The paper presents positive results showing that certain pairs of Banach spaces satisfy the sbpbp, particularly when @xmath0 is uniformly convex or when @xmath1 has the Schur property. It also provides a characterization of uniformly convex Banach spaces in terms of the sbpbp.

• Negative results are presented, demonstrating that there exist uniformly convex Banach spaces and infinite-dimensional Banach spaces for which the sbpbp does not hold, using the uniform sbpbp as a starting point.

• The paper concludes with a complete characterization of the sbpbp for pairs of Banach spaces, identifying specific cases where the property holds and others where it does not, and providing examples of Banach spaces that fail the sbpbp under various conditions.

<summary>
• Low - luminosity active galactic nuclei ( LLAGNs) are prevalent in about 40% of nearby bright galaxies and are thought to be caused by low accretion rates onto super-massive black holes, often explained by the advection - dominated accretion flow (ADAF) model.
• Observations at centimetre bands have been challenging due to contamination from jets, but high-frequency observations promise to reveal the ADAF's predicted submillimetre bump.
• The study reports millimetre survey and submillimetre data analyses for many LLAGNs, using the Noyama Millimetre Array (NMA) and archival data from the James Clerk Maxwell Telescope (JCMT).
• The sample includes 20 LLAGNs detected with VLBI, with the remaining five newly detected but unpublished.
• The study finds inverted spectra at high frequencies (15-96 GHz) in at least half of the LLAGNs, suggesting the presence of the ADAF.
• Submillimetre fluxes measured with the SCUBA on the JCMT are used to estimate dust contamination in the NMA measurements.
• The study confirms little diffuse contamination from dust, free-free, and extended nonthermal emissions in LLAGNs with inverted spectra, indicating intrinsic properties of the cores.
• An inverse correlation between high-frequency radio spectrum and low-frequency radio core power is found, suggesting that the disc components could be seen only if the jets are faint.
• The study concludes that the inverted high-frequency radio spectra are potential signatures of the ADAF, encouraging further surveys at higher frequencies.
• The existence of the ADAF would allow radio astronomers to directly image accretion discs, which has been limited to nonthermal phenomena in relativistic jets.
• The study acknowledges the contributions of S. Okumura for advice on NMA observations.
• The Noyama Radio Observatory and the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan are credited for extensive use of NVSS and JCMT data.
• The study mentions the upcoming VSOP-2 space VLBI mission, which could

• The article explores static disk solutions in general relativity, focusing on disks made of perfect fluid with equal radial and azimuthal pressures, and disks with halos also made of perfect fluid. These solutions are generated using the "displace, cut, and reflect" method applied to spherically symmetric solutions of Einstein's field equations.
• The method involves inverting a non-singular part of space to create a disk with a singularity, and matching conditions are applied to ensure physical properties like zero pressure at the boundary and continuity of metric functions and their derivatives.
• The study includes various models of disks with halos constructed from exact solutions of static spheres of perfect fluid, with parameters chosen to ensure stable orbits and velocities less than the speed of light.
• The results show that these disk models can describe more realistic astrophysical objects like galaxies without requiring the counter-rotating matter hypothesis for stability, and they exhibit common features such as decreasing surface energy density and pressures with radius, and regions of unstable orbits for highly relativistic disks.

• The Space Time Explorer & Quantum Equivalence Principle Space Test (STE-QUEST) is a medium-sized mission candidate for launch in 2022/2024, aiming to test Einstein's equivalence principle by measuring gravitational red-shift with high accuracy and comparing it with the weak equivalence principle using atom interferometry.
• The mission design, developed by Astrium, addresses challenges such as payload power demands, thermal stability, and communication link performance, with a focus on minimizing micro-vibrations and ensuring precise orbit determination.

• The study presents a geometrical method for classifying and visualizing homogeneous isotropic cosmologies in multi-scalar models with arbitrary scalar potentials, focusing on the implications of scalar field potentials for cosmological acceleration.
• It demonstrates that flat cosmologies are geodesics in an augmented target space and that accelerating cosmologies correspond to geodesics that bend into an acceleration cone within this space, with the potential's sign determining the nature of the geodesic (timelike, null, or spacelike). The method also extends to 'doubly-augmented' target spaces for non-flat cosmologies, providing a framework for understanding the late-time behavior of cosmologies in models with various scalar potentials.

• The bosonic Mott-Hubbard model describes the quantum phase transition between superfluid and insulating states in optical lattices, with the ratio of on-site energy to bandwidth as a key parameter.
• Perturbation theory is used to improve the Gutzwiller mean-field approximation by including short-range correlations, providing corrections to local observables and momentum distribution expansion patterns.
• Numerical calculations show that perturbation theory modifies the particle number fluctuations and the correlation function, leading to a smoother transition at the Mott-insulator phase and affecting the expansion patterns in both homogeneous and inhomogeneous lattices.
• The perturbative approach reveals complex modifications to expansion patterns in the presence of harmonic confinement, with significant implications for experimental observations of the Mott transition.

• The paper explores the quark-gluon plasma (QGP) phase of quantum chromodynamics (QCD), focusing on the transition to this state under varying temperatures and baryon densities, using the one-gluon exchange interaction within the Landau Fermi liquid theory framework.
• The study reveals that the QGP phase is more likely to form at lower baryon densities and temperatures when considering the repulsive one-gluon exchange interaction, as opposed to the non-interacting case.
• The phase diagram indicates that the QGP phase is more stable than strange quark matter, with the free energy of QGP being larger than that of strange quark matter.
• The study suggests that future work could adjust the phase diagram to relate the bag constant and the QCD coupling constant, and could also incorporate gluon interactions and variable coupling and bag pressures.

* The conformally symmetric model for strong interactions suggests the existence of a light scalar field associated with quark confinement, with a mass around 38 mev, which could be a higgs-like particle for strong interactions.
* The model predicts small flavor-independent oscillations in electron-positron and proton-antiproton annihilation data, and an interference effect in babar data around the 38 mev resonance, hinting at the existence of a light scalar glueball.
* The model also suggests the existence of two heavier replicas of the light scalar boson, with masses two and three times heavier than the light scalar, and a possible @xmath0 hybrid with a mass enhancement in babar data.

* The study presents a full-scale numerical simulation of high-frequency electromagnetic wave propagation into the ionosphere, with parameters typical for the EISCAT heating facility in Troms, Norway.
* The simulation demonstrates reflection of the l-mode and r-x-mode at different altitudes, mode conversion of the l-mode into electrostatic langmuir/upper hybrid waves, and nonlinear harmonic generation of high-frequency waves.
* The simulation results suggest that such simulations can become a powerful tool for studying HF-induced ionospheric turbulence and secondary radiation quantitatively, for direct comparison with experimental data.
* The study also discusses the mode conversion of the l-mode into electrostatic waves and the generation of second harmonic frequencies, which have been observed in ionospheric heating experiments.
* The simulation neglects the em field falloff, the fresnel pattern, and the influence of field-aligned irregularities in the ionosphere.
* The simulation uses the MKS system of units and assumes a vertically stratified ion number density profile with a constant geomagnetic field directed obliquely to the density gradient.
* The em wave is injected vertically into the ionosphere, and the simulation shows the different behaviors of the l-mode and r-x-mode, including their reflection and mode conversion processes.

<summary>
* The study explores domain walls in binary Bose-Einstein condensates (BECs) with a coupling drive, which are not topologically stable and can decay.
* The domain walls are characterized by a change in relative phase between two condensates by @xmath0.
* The stability of the domain walls is metastable when the rabi frequency is below a critical value, which is of the order @xmath109 hz for typical experimental parameters.
* The decay of domain walls can occur via thermal activation, but the rate is exponentially suppressed at temperatures achieved in current experiments.
* The domain walls can be interpreted as membranes with vortices at their boundaries, and the energy barrier for decay is related to the vortex tension.
* Theoretical analysis shows that the domain walls are metastable when the width of the wall is much larger than the correlation length of relative density fluctuations.
* The decay rate is exponentially suppressed at low temperatures, suggesting that domain walls could exist in current experimental setups.
* The creation of domain walls in experiments could be achieved by controlling the coupling drive and the relative motion of the condensates.
* The domain walls have a rich interpretation in terms of particle number conversion and flow between the two condensates.
* The existence of domain walls in binary BECs is analogous to phenomena in particle physics, such as axion domain walls and quark matter.
* The study provides a mathematical framework for understanding the properties and dynamics of domain walls in binary BECs.
* The authors acknowledge support from various institutions and individuals for their research.
* The paper concludes with a discussion on the experimental realization of domain walls in binary BECs and the potential for future experiments.
* Appendices provide detailed stability analysis and decay mechanisms for domain walls.
* The work suggests that domain walls in binary BECs could be a new avenue for exploring quantum phenomena in ultra-cold atomic systems.
</summary>

* Anomalies in quantum field theory occur when classical symmetries are violated upon quantization, leading to inconsistencies if internal symmetries break down.
* External symmetry breakdown, like in @xmath0-decay, is not problematic, but internal symmetry breakdown, such as gauge symmetry, results in anomalies that can destroy renormalizability and unitarity.
* The study of gravitational anomalies, including the einstein and Weyl anomalies, began with alvarez-gaum and witten in the 1980s, and has been approached through various methods, including heat kernel, path integral, and modern mathematical techniques.
* The paper focuses on calculating gravitational anomalies and Schwinger terms using dispersion relations (DR), an alternative to ultraviolet regularization.
* In two dimensions, the method of DR is shown to be equivalent to dimensional regularization (DR) for calculating anomalies, with the key difference being the treatment of infrared divergences.
* The paper demonstrates that the anomalous ward identities and trace identities for the energy-momentum tensor are independent of the renormalization procedure, relying only on the finite formfactor.
* The origin of the anomaly in the DR approach is a superconvergence sum rule for the imaginary part of a specific formfactor, which exhibits an @xmath0-function singularity in the infrared limit.
* The paper calculates the linearized gravitational anomalies, the covariant einstein anomaly, and the linearized weyl anomaly, showing equivalence with results obtained through dimensional regularization.
* The gravitational Schwinger terms, related to the curvature of the determinant line bundle, are also calculated using a dispersive approach adapted from klln's method.
* The paper concludes that the DR approach provides an independent and complementary view of anomalies, with practical advantages in two dimensions, and suggests potential applicability in higher dimensions.

* The paper presents a supersymmetric extension of the Mavanas model, incorporating supersymmetry breaking mediated by gravity.
* A chiral superfield in the dark sector, interacting with the hidden sector through gravity, is introduced, leading to a variable neutrino mass and dark energy density.
* The scalar potential for the acceleron includes terms from supersymmetry breaking effects, with the gravitino mass being a small but favored value.
* The model predicts slow evolution of the sterile neutrino mass and the equation of state parameter, ensuring hydrodynamic stability and avoiding the dark energy instability.
* The sterile neutrino mass variation is small, within the limits set by cosmic microwave background observations.
* The model accommodates both cases of vanishing and finite mixing between left-handed and sterile neutrinos.
* The framework suggests a mechanism for supersymmetry breaking in the dark sector, with the breaking scale expected to be in the teV range.
* The model's predictions are consistent with the observed flatness and accelerated expansion of the universe, without fine-tuning issues.
* The paper concludes that the supersymmetric Mavans model with gravity-mediated supersymmetry breaking can explain the origin of dark energy and its connection to particle physics.

• A faint, red star at a specific angular separation from the active star HIP 115147 was identified as a candidate nearby low-mass dwarf, LSPM J2322 + 7847, from the LSPM North catalog.
• New photometry and preliminary trigonometric parallax astrometry were obtained for LSPM J2322 + 7847, suggesting it is a young, nearby low-mass dwarf at a distance of approximately 20 parsecs.
• The system, including HIP 115147 and its companions, is discussed in terms of possible young age and origin, with the age estimated to be around 20-50 million years based on isochrone fitting.
• The system's proper motion difference may indicate a systematic error in nomad proper motions for faint stars, suggesting the companions are not gravitationally bound as a multiple system.
• The system's age and origin are consistent with it being a young, later-type star in the solar neighborhood, possibly related to the ophiuchus star-forming region.
• The system's distance is estimated to be about 20 parsecs based on trigonometric parallax measurements.
• The system's activity and characteristics are compared with other young stars in the solar neighborhood, suggesting it is older than the TWA association but younger than classical T Tauri stars.
• The research was conducted at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory and utilized data from the SIMBAD database and the 2MASS project.

• The study confirms the predominance of @xmath0gap symmetry in high-temperature superconductors (HTS) up to the critical temperature @xmath1, with minor components smaller than 5%.
• The research addresses the temperature range at which nodal characteristics of the gap are observable through thermal conductivity and whether thermal activation of quasiparticles can explain experimental results across the entire temperature range.
• Numerical calculations using a two-dimensional brt expression for thermal conductivity and an andreev reflection model for quasiparticle scattering by vortices align well with experimental data, supporting the @xmath0-gap symmetry.
• The study suggests that the mechanisms influencing quasiparticle behavior in HTS are well described by fermi liquid theory at nearly optimal doping, and small differences in angle patterns between twinned and untwinned samples can be attributed to impurity concentration and oxygen deficiency.

<summary>
• The paper introduces and studies the phenomenon of stochastic resonance in the context of signal detection through noise in ergodic diffusion processes, differing from current literature by continuous-time data collection and non-i.i.d. noise structure.
• Two observation schemes are proposed: observing the time the perturbed signal exceeds a threshold, and measuring the energy of the signal above the threshold.
• Asymptotic properties of estimators for both schemes are established using the generalized method of moments, showing that they are asymptotically equivalent to maximum likelihood estimators.
• Fisher information quantity is used to identify optimal noise levels for signal detection, revealing stochastic resonance where the information peaks at certain noise levels.
• The paper also addresses hypothesis testing for signal detection, showing that the overall probability of error can exhibit a nonmonotonic dependence on noise level due to stochastic resonance.
• The phenomenon of stochastic resonance is noted for the first time in this context, with the probability of error minimized at certain noise levels.
• The paper concludes with the potential power of ergodic diffusions as noise in enhancing stochastic resonance, suggesting further research on parametric and nonparametric signal models.
• The work is organized into sections covering model setup, time and energy observation schemes, asymptotic properties, hypothesis testing, and numerical examples illustrating stochastic resonance.
• The paper references various works on stochastic resonance, ergodic diffusion processes, and statistical estimation methods.
• Figures illustrating the concepts and findings are included at the end of the paper.
</summary>

* The Norris survey of the Corona Borealis supercluster reveals evolution in the local galaxy luminosity function ( LF), with the population of blue, star-forming galaxies becoming more luminous with increasing redshift. This evolution is reflected in the larger fraction of galaxies at higher redshift exhibiting spectral signatures of ongoing star formation, without evidence for short-term bursts of star formation.
* The LFs of the two superclusters, Corona Borealis and Abell 2069, show significant differences from the field LF, despite overall similarity. The superclusters contain an excess of very bright galaxies, likely giant ellipticals in dense regions, with spectra dominated by an old, red stellar population. There is suggestive evidence of a sharp upturn in the supercluster LF for the least luminous galaxies, which is not as pronounced in the local field LF.

• The study presents a robust sample of 19 starburst galaxies ( smgs) selected using scuba and mambo in the lockman hole, with 15 detected securely by deep radio imaging and 10 spectroscopic redshifts considered secure. The median redshift of the full spectroscopic sample is 2.14, consistent with previous larger samples. The sample supports the conclusion that the bright smg population is amenable to study via radio-selected samples down to a flux density limit of 850 mJy.

• The analysis also re-calibrates the relationship between positional accuracy, beam size, and significance for future wide-field surveys, suggesting that the current requirement for deep radio coverage may not be as urgent if deployable integral-field units are used for spectroscopic follow-up. The study concludes that a significant fraction of bright smgs likely do not lie at very high redshifts and are accessible for study via radio-selected samples.

• The paper presents numerical methods for solving initial value systems of two-dimensional convection-diffusion equations using modified cubic B-splines differential quadrature method (DQM) with new sets of modified cubic B-splines as base functions, specifically modified trigonometric, exponential, and third-order extended cubic B-splines DQM (mtb-DQM, mexp-DQM, and mecdq methods). These methods transform the convection-diffusion problem into a system of first-order ODEs, which are then solved using the SSP-RK54 time integration scheme.

• The stability of the proposed methods is analyzed, confirming that they produce stable solutions for two-dimensional convection-diffusion equations. The methods are found to be more accurate and have a good agreement with exact solutions compared to existing schemes. The order of accuracy for dirichlet boundary conditions is cubic, while for neumann boundary conditions, it is quadratic.

• Three test problems are numerically solved using the proposed methods, demonstrating their effectiveness and accuracy. The results are in good agreement with exact solutions, and the methods show a linear or quadratic rate of convergence.

* Anomaly - mediated supersymmetry breaking ( amsb ) models have been popular due to their calculable soft terms and flavor invariance, but suffer from negative slepton mass squared parameters.
* Hypercharged anomaly - mediation ( hcamsb ) is an alternative setup that localizes susy breaking at the bottom of a warped hidden region, suppressing gravity mediation contributions.
* The hcamsb model's parameter space is defined by a dimensionless quantity, and it predicts different mass spectra compared to the minimal amsb model.
* The hcamsb model's scalar masses and superpotential term decrease with a parameter, leading to distinctive mass splittings and decay patterns.
* The hcamsb model's lhc reach is similar to mamsb for low @xmath0 but differs for large @xmath0, with a higher multiplicity of @xmath32 jets expected.
* The hcamsb model's lightest squarks are expected to be lighter than the gluino mass, leading to cascade decays with large quark multiplicities.
* The hcamsb model's lightest stau state is expected to be mainly left-handed, and the @xmath14 gaugino mass @xmath16 is expected to be the largest, influencing the neutralino composition.
* The hcamsb model's mass ordering can lead to a prominent @xmath12 peak in dilepton distributions, potentially distinguishing it from mamsb models at the lhc.
* The hcamsb model's predictions for lhc searches include differences in event topologies and dilepton distributions, which may serve as signatures for distinguishing between the two models.

<summary>
• Dehn surgery is an operation to modify a three-manifold by drilling and regluing a solid torus, denoted by @xmath0 in @xmath1 along a slope @xmath2.
• The cosmetic surgery conjecture posits that two surgeries on inequivalent slopes are never purely cosmetic.
• The paper shows that for most knots in @xmath3, @xmath4 for distinct slopes @xmath5 and @xmath6.
• A sufficient condition for a knot to admit no purely cosmetic surgery is given in terms of its Jones polynomial @xmath7 and its derivatives.
• The paper introduces an invariant @xmath8, satisfying a crossing change formula, as a new ingredient for the cosmetic surgery problem.
• The paper proves that if a knot has either @xmath9 or @xmath10, then it admits no purely cosmetic surgeries for any two distinct slopes.
• The paper derives an explicit formula for the finite type invariant @xmath11, which is a reformulation of the main result in terms of finite type invariants.
• The paper proves the nonexistence of purely cosmetic surgeries for certain families of two-bridge knots and whitehead doubles.
• The paper observes that the cosmetic surgery conjecture is true for all knots with no more than @xmath12 crossings, except possibly @xmath13.
• The paper shows that the results from heegaard floer theory and the crossing change formula for the Jones polynomial are independent and complementary.
• The paper acknowledges the support of the authors and references relevant literature.
• The paper includes a detailed proof of the main theorem and applications to specific knots, as well as a connection to perturbative and quantum invariants.
• The paper concludes with a discussion of the implications of the results for the study of three-manifolds and knot theory.
• The paper includes figures illustrating the concepts discussed, such as the conway form of two-bridge knots and the positive @xmath79-twisted whitehead double.
