<summary>
• The invention relates to seismometers, particularly ocean bottom seismometers (OBS), and provides a method and apparatus for determining the angle of inclination of such units during operation and for leveling their seismic motion detectors.
• The invention addresses challenges in positioning OBS on the ocean floor, where the exact nature of the surface is unknown, potentially affecting seismic coupling and data quality.
• It offers a simple, inexpensive method to determine the seismometer's angle of inclination, aiding in understanding the ocean floor's contour and the seismometer's precise location.
• The invention includes a device for automatically leveling seismic motion detectors, ensuring good acoustic coupling between the ocean bottom and the detector.
• The apparatus preserves the orientation of the leveled seismic detectors, allowing for later determination of the seismometer's angle of inclination.
• The invention comprises a seismometer with a frame, floats, an instrument compartment, and a ballast tube, with the detector mounted on the door of a water-tight housing for improved seismic coupling.
• The seismometer's normal position is defined as when it is placed on a flat, horizontal surface, with a spherical ball forming a simple pendulum to align the detector with the vertical.
• A plunger mechanism, controlled by a solenoid, locks the detector in its assumed orientation when the seismometer is deployed.
• The angle of inclination can be determined by measuring the acute angle formed by a line through the detector's center of gravity and the spherical ball's center when the seismometer is clamped.
• The invention includes a mounting plate with a stop ring to prevent damage during handling and a second coil spring to engage the pin when the plunger is extended.
• The solenoid activates to retract the pin, locking the detector in position, and the angle of inclination can be measured relative to a known vertical surface.
• The invention is applicable to both vertical and horizontal seismic motion detectors, with the orientation of the detectors being parallel or perpendicular to the line through the detector's center of gravity

• The invention relates to a method of manufacturing a semiconductor device with an improved LDD structure, allowing for better control over the oxide film width on the gate sidewall and preventing device degradation due to hot carrier injection.
• The invention also includes various embodiments where the gate sidewall oxide film is formed using different materials as masks, and the LDD structure is formed through ion injection processes, with some embodiments utilizing silicidation to enhance device performance.

• The invention relates to a multiorifice structure and method for fabricating it, specifically for use in automotive fuel injector valves to atomize fuel.
• The structure is created by fusing concentric layers of solid rods and cylindrical members at increasing angles, forming angularly disposed passageways that enhance fluid atomization.
• The fabrication method involves fusing layers of rods and cylindrical members, with the possibility of coating them with a lower melting temperature material for easier fusion, and then slicing the assembly to produce thin multiorifice structures.

• The invention relates to wireless communication systems, specifically for detecting, identifying, and monitoring multipath signals in WCDMA systems, with a focus on 3G systems that aim to improve transmission speeds and add mobile services.
• The system includes an antenna, RF subsystem with high and low frequency oscillators, and a baseband subsystem with a free-running counter that provides a mobile time reference, maintaining accuracy during idle and active modes.
• The invention also includes a multipath monitor and recovery circuit that utilizes a mobile time reference for efficient signal recovery, with benefits such as reduced power consumption and improved signal identification.

• The invention introduces an enhanced radio telephone that can function as an improved IP telephone by connecting to a PC, reducing the need for high-performance PCs and extra sound equipment.
• The enhanced radio telephone includes an internal speech coder for low power consumption, allowing it to be used with lower-cost PCs for effective IP telephony.
• The system can switch between wireless and IP telephony modes manually or automatically, with control initiated from either the PC or the radio handset.
• The enhanced radio telephone can also be used for wireless data communication, carrying IP speech over a wireless network interface.
• The invention allows for the use of standard PC connections (serial or parallel ports) for digital speech and control signaling, making the system more convenient and economical.
• The invention provides an improved IP telephone that is more convenient, economical, and efficient than conventional IP telephony systems, with various embodiments offering different configurations for specific applications.

• The invention introduces a humidity sensing element that is energized by low voltage microscopic currents, does not rely on mechanical movements, and is robust against environmental factors such as fingerprints or dirt. It offers a response time of about one second and is made using a novel combination of manufacturing methods.
• The element consists of a first electrode made from anodizable metal, a dielectric coating with deposited conductive particles, and a second electrode formed by vacuum deposition of metal. The impedance between the electrodes varies linearly with relative humidity when excited by an alternating current voltage.
• The preferred embodiment uses aluminum and nickel, with the aluminum anodized and sealed to form a dielectric coating, and the nickel deposited in the interstices to form the second electrode. The sensor is suitable for excitation by a 10 Hertz sine wave alternating current voltage and is designed for use in environments with temperatures between 75° F. and 85° F. and relative humidities between 40% and 85%.

* The invention relates to a helmet liner that can be rapidly and simply fitted to an individual's head and adjusted for size changes.
* The liner is made of multiple elastic thermoplastic sheets with pockets, arranged in contact with each other, allowing for compliance and conformity to the wearer's head shape.
* The liner pockets are open and unfilled, avoiding the need for registration with adjacent layers, simplifying manufacturing and allowing for better conformity to head contours.
* The liner can be heated to a plastic state, fitted to the head, and then cooled to retain its shape, accommodating size changes without the need for drawstrings or trimming.
* The liner can be refitted for different individuals or the same individual with a changed head size, as long as the new size is larger than the previous size.
* The manufacturing process is relatively simple and inexpensive, and the liner does not shift position on the wearer's head.
* The liner does not require tension maintenance during fitting, unlike previous designs that used drawstrings.
* The invention is not limited to the specific details shown and described, allowing for various changes within the scope of the claims.

* The invention introduces an improved tool-fixing mechanism for a wide range of machining applications, including robotics and pneumatic tools, where tool and counterpart (e.g., cushion) are fixed to a tool holder in a machine tool frame.
* The mechanism features curved connecting surfaces between the tool frame and tool holder, allowing for secure and simple tool placement and force transmission during machining.
* The curved surfaces are designed to meet a specific geometric relationship, ensuring proper fit and force transmission, with adjustable clearance for different tool types.
* The invention also includes a release mechanism that allows for tool and frame removal without disturbing the machining process, using a ball mechanism for controlled movement.

* The invention addresses the issue of transversely located cigarettes in cigarette magazines of cigarette-production and packaging machines, which can block shafts and disrupt production.
* An optical checking element, such as a camera, scans images of cigarettes in the magazine, and an image-processing device evaluates these images against reference images or values to detect deviations.
* If a deviation is detected, an error signal is produced, which can trigger an ejecting unit to automatically remove the misaligned cigarettes.
* The ejecting unit, arranged in the magazine, has a housing with a linear cylinder for guiding a carriage connected to an ejector, which pushes cigarettes out of the magazine into an inclined chute for recycling.
* The system can be configured with multiple cameras and ejecting units, each assigned to specific zones, allowing for efficient detection and removal of misaligned cigarettes without affecting the entire magazine width.
* The ejecting units are designed to prevent jamming and allow for manual triggering or sampling, enhancing flexibility and reliability.
* The invention aims to reduce labor-intensive monitoring, minimize human error, and improve overall production efficiency by automatically detecting and eliminating defective or incorrectly positioned cigarettes.

* The invention relates to scraped surface heat exchangers, specifically the mounting of blades onto the central drive shaft.
* Blades are hingedly connected to the drive shaft with pins and are designed to prevent lateral movement while allowing angular movement.
* The invention addresses the issue of blades swinging outwardly and potentially falling during installation, especially in vertically arranged heat exchangers.
* The invention introduces an L-shaped locking track system on both sides of the blade, which prevents lateral movement and allows the blade to be installed at an angle.
* The locking tracks are designed to ensure that the blade remains in the correct orientation and does not fall off the pins during installation or removal.
* The invention allows for the blades to be installed with the correct side facing up, ensuring the scraper edge is correctly oriented against the inner surface of the outer tube.
* The invention's locking tracks are advantageous as they can be placed on both sides of the blade, reducing wear and maintaining structural rigidity.
* The invention is not limited to the specific construction and operation illustrated, and can be practiced in various ways, with equivalent constructions falling within its scope.
* The invention provides significant benefits for the installation and operation of scraped surface heat exchangers, particularly in preventing blade misalignment and ensuring correct orientation.

• Vehicle battery rebalancing involves equalizing cell voltages by bleeding down cells with higher voltages until all cells have approximately equal voltages, with continuous monitoring during the process.
• Rebalancing can consume up to 50% of the total time for recharging a battery, which can be lengthy for plug-in hybrid electric vehicles or battery electric vehicles with significant cell imbalances.
• The invention proposes systems and techniques to minimize rebalancing and charging time, optimizing battery pack charge time and energy content to support a target drive range efficiently.

<summary>
• The invention relates to switching circuitry for driving display drivers with high efficiency and low electromagnetic interference (EMI).
• It addresses the limitations of charge pumps and switching regulators, which typically generate noise and have lower current driving capabilities.
• The invention modifies switching regulators to create multiple paths that carry current in opposite directions, canceling out radiated noise.
• Additional terminal lines are provided to sink any EMI generated in the outermost paths connected to the circuit.
• The invention enables the production of large amounts of current for large displays without the typical EMI penalties.
• The invention includes a schematic diagram of a switching regulator and a control timing diagram to illustrate its operation.
• The invention also shows a conventional implementation of a switching regulator and a modified version with reduced EMI.
• The invention provides methods and apparatus for producing sufficient current to drive circuits for large displays with low EMI, potentially improving the quality of transmitted and received signals.
• The invention may also include additional terminal paths to further reduce EMI effects.
</summary>

* The invention relates to devices for generating electrical power from surface waves, utilizing submerged containers that expand and contract due to hydrostatic pressure differences and/or surge or pitch, enhanced by wave focusing or reflection.
* The invention aims to capture a substantial portion of wave energy, which is more efficient and cost-effective compared to existing ocean wave energy converters (OWECs).
* The invention addresses the limitations of prior art OWECs, such as high costs, low efficiency, and inability to adjust depth for tidal variations.
* The invention uses gas-filled containers with flexible, reinforced bellows that are submerged below wave troughs and connected to floating surfaces or buoys.
* The containers' expansion and contraction are enhanced by partial evacuation or venting to atmospheric pressure, increasing stroke and energy capture.
* The invention allows for adjustable depth to maintain efficiency across varying sea states and tides, and can be oriented in multiple directions for capturing different wave energy components.
* The invention employs mechanical or electrical drive means to convert the linear motion of container expansion and contraction into rotational motion for power generation.
* The invention can produce electrical power ranging from 0.25 MW to 1 MW, with potential for larger devices.
* The invention's design reduces mass and cost, increases responsiveness, and allows for effective timing of energy capture strokes.
* The invention can be combined with wave reflection and focusing techniques to further increase energy capture efficiency.
* The invention's design eliminates the need for heavy, maintenance-intensive marine structures and fragile seal mechanisms.
* The invention's design allows for scalability and can be adapted for various wave conditions and energy capture needs.

• The invention is an AC-to-DC converter lamp power supply that eliminates low and high frequency flicker, reducing eye fatigue and protecting health. It allows for constant brightness adjustment and has no electromagnetic radiation.
• The converter includes various circuits for input protection, EMI filtering, rectification, filtering, conversion, output filtering, lamp connection, start-up, control, feedback, dimming, and protection, with the ability to integrate or modify these components.
• The invention can be used in various applications requiring AC to DC conversion, such as lighting, power supplies, and chargers, and can be implemented using different topologies and control methods.

• Current surface transportation programs lack a clear vision and effective linkage to performance, leading to inefficient allocation of funds and fiscal sustainability issues.
• A fundamental reexamination and restructuring of federal programs are needed to create more focused, performance-based, and sustainable programs, with a vision and strategy to address national transportation needs and priorities.

• The invention relates to a system for automatic control of lighting levels in a space, using both electric lighting and motorized window treatments to maintain a desired illumination profile and minimize sun glare. It includes a central processor, dimming panel, photosensors, and window treatment controllers, with the ability to create custom lighting scenes and respond to daylight changes. The system can operate in open loop or closed loop modes for electric lighting and window treatments, with the latter also incorporating glare control based on sun angle.
• The system can maintain multiple lighting profiles throughout the day, with the ability to adjust electric lighting and window treatments to compensate for varying daylight levels. It includes a process for calibrating lighting presets and a method for controlling electric lights and window treatments based on light level readings, with adjustments for different types of light sources and spectral sensitivities.
• The system can also incorporate manual overrides for window treatments and adjust for glare control based on sun angle, using a dead-band approach and variable set points that change according to the time of day and sun angle.

• The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 (LDA) and Internal Revenue Code (IRC) sections 4911 and 162(e) have different purposes and definitions of lobbying, with LDA focusing on public disclosure of federal lobbying efforts and IRC sections 4911 and 162(e) addressing tax-exempt status and deductibility of lobbying expenses for businesses and tax-exempt organizations, respectively. LDA requires registration and semiannual reporting of lobbying expenses and activities, while IRC sections 4911 and 162(e) do not. LDA covers federal lobbying exclusively, while IRC definitions include state and local lobbying, and IRC section 162(e) has exceptions that could exclude significant lobbying expenses from coverage. The differences in definitions can affect registration and reporting requirements, potentially leading to less public disclosure of lobbying activities than intended by LDA. Options to address these discrepancies include harmonizing the definitions, eliminating the use of IRC definitions for LDA reporting, or requiring organizations to report only federal lobbying expenses when using IRC definitions.

* The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has made significant progress in aviation security since September 2001, implementing numerous mandates and deadlines set by the Aviation and Transportation Security Act (ATSA), including deploying federal screeners and deploying explosives detection technology at airports. However, challenges remain, such as ensuring the security of air traffic control systems, managing airport access controls, and addressing vulnerabilities in air cargo, general aviation, and airport perimeter security.
* TSA has taken steps to improve security, such as establishing a Transportation Workers Identification Card (TWIC) program, developing the Computer Assisted Passenger Prescreening System (CAPPS II), and initiating a registered traveler program. However, concerns about privacy, funding, and the effectiveness of these initiatives persist.
* Long-term challenges for TSA include risk management, funding, coordination, strategic human capital management, and building a results-oriented organization. TSA must also continue to address vulnerabilities in air cargo, general aviation, and airport perimeter security, and ensure the security of air traffic control systems and facilities.
* TSA's efforts to strengthen aviation security are supported by various legislative proposals and funding mechanisms, but the agency faces challenges in maintaining and sustaining security advancements, managing its workforce, and coordinating with federal, state, and local agencies.

<summary>
• The SEC's financial statements for fiscal years 2007 and 2006 were fairly stated, but internal control weaknesses may lead to inaccuracies in financial reporting and performance information.
• SEC has identified material weaknesses and significant deficiencies in internal control, particularly in financial reporting processes, information security, and property and equipment accounting, which could affect management decisions and require corrective actions.
</summary>

* The Institute of Medicine's report in 1993 revealed that an estimated 60,000 military personnel were human experimental subjects in U.S. chemical weapons tests during World War II, with additional servicemembers potentially exposed through production, transportation, and storage.
* In response to congressional and executive interest, the Department of Defense (DOD) established the Chemical Weapons Exposure Study Task Force, which identified approximately 6,400 servicemembers and civilians potentially exposed to chemical substances, and developed a database to track these individuals.
* Despite DOD's efforts, additional servicemembers and civilians potentially exposed to Project 112 tests have been identified through non-DOD sources since DOD ceased active searches in 2003, raising questions about the completeness and accuracy of DOD's efforts.
* DOD's current effort to identify individuals exposed to chemical or biological substances outside of Project 112 lacks clear objectives, scope, oversight, and transparency, and has not effectively coordinated with other entities or notified civilians potentially exposed.

* The Food Stamp Program, administered by FNS, provides food assistance to eligible low-income households, with states responsible for certifying eligibility and managing program administration, including benefit calculations and error monitoring.
* FNS introduced options and waivers to increase access and reduce reporting burdens, such as extending eligibility to TANF-funded services, modifying vehicle asset rules, and offering alternative reporting periods and methods.
* States face challenges in minimizing payment errors and simplifying program administration, with some considering the Simplified Food Stamp Program and Transitional Benefit Alternative to address these issues, though implementation complexities and costs have limited widespread adoption.

<summary>
• NCHIP, a federal grant program managed by BJS, aims to enhance the quality, completeness, and accessibility of the nation's criminal history and sex offender record systems, facilitating interstate exchange of information for various purposes including firearms background checks and noncriminal justice uses.
• States use NCHIP funds for various purposes, with the majority allocated to NICS/III/criminal records improvements and disposition reporting improvements, which directly impact NICS operations.
• Automation of criminal history records and compliance with FBI standards for national data systems have improved, with states investing significantly in technology and system upgrades beyond the required 10 percent match for NCHIP funds.
• Despite progress, challenges remain in automating disposition information and identifying prohibited firearm purchasers, such as those with misdemeanor domestic violence convictions or mental health adjudications.
• The demand for background checks is growing due to employment screening requirements and homeland security concerns, necessitating ongoing technological upgrades and improvements in record accessibility and automation.
• NCHIP serves as an "umbrella" and "partnership" program, pooling various funding streams and coordinating efforts to modernize state information systems, with states contributing more than the required match and utilizing additional federal and state funds for system improvements.
• The future of NCHIP involves continued collaboration between federal, state, and local entities to sustain and advance national infrastructure for criminal history records, with considerations for technological advancements, funding stability, and addressing gaps in record automation and accessibility.
</summary>

<summary>
• GAO has assessed strategic sourcing in federal acquisitions for over a decade, noting companies' shift to aggregate procurement approaches and structural changes for leveraging buying power.
• Strategic sourcing includes tactics like leveraged buying, demand management, process standardization, total cost of ownership evaluation, and supplier relationship management, with spend analysis as a key component since 2002.
• Federal agencies, due to decentralized procurement, have not fully leveraged their buying power, with the FSSI established in 2005 to coordinate strategic sourcing efforts across agencies.
• Despite FSSI efforts, most federal agencies only managed a small fraction of spending through strategic sourcing in fiscal year 2011, with significant savings potential in services procurement untapped.
• Agencies face challenges in data reliability, expertise, leadership commitment, and metrics for strategic sourcing, with only 15% of FSSI-covered spending managed through FSSI contracts in fiscal year 2011.
• Leading companies have successfully applied strategic sourcing to services, achieving savings of 4-15% by analyzing spending, centralizing procurement, and focusing on total cost of ownership, contrary to federal agencies' reluctance to strategically source services.
• GAO's 2012 report highlighted the need for improved strategic sourcing in the federal government, recommending actions for DOD, VA, and OMB to enhance strategic sourcing efforts.
• Despite some progress, federal agencies have not fully adopted strategic sourcing, with DOD and VA still developing comprehensive lists of strategic sourcing efforts and focusing on high spending categories.
• OMB has directed agencies to strategically source at least two new products or services yielding at least 10% savings, with some agencies taking leadership roles in strategic sourcing initiatives.
• Companies have demonstrated that strategic sourcing can yield savings and efficiencies, with a focus on dynamic, category-specific strategies rather than a one-size-fits-all approach.

<summary>
• FAA engages in aviation safety oversight, ATC, and airport infrastructure development, with costs varying based on service usage and nature.
• Safety activities costs are driven by volume, while ATC services are influenced by flight types and peak periods.
• General aviation (GA) flight usage of ATC services varies, with some flights operating under VFR and not requiring ATC services.
• Airport Improvement Program (AIP) funding for airport infrastructure is based on congressional priorities, not directly on user costs.
• The Airport and Airway Revenue Act of 1970 established the Trust Fund to support airport and airway system development, with revenues exceeding spending commitments historically.
• Trust Fund revenues have been less than forecasted in recent years, leading to a decline in the uncommitted balance.
• The National Civil Aviation Review Commission recommended linking FAA revenues more closely to service costs and using General Fund revenues for aviation security and safety activities.
• Current funding structure raises concerns about revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency due to the disconnect between costs and revenues from users.
• Stakeholders debate the fairness of the current funding structure, with GA operators arguing for incremental cost charges and commercial operators favoring proportional cost distribution.
• Alternative funding options include modifying excise taxes, implementing direct user charges, and using debt financing for capital projects, each with their own advantages and disadvantages.
• The report suggests a combination of funding options may best address concerns, but acknowledges the need for a comprehensive cost accounting system to accurately allocate costs among users.
• Both DOT and Treasury have concerns about the current funding structure and the potential impact of debt financing on FAA's operations and the federal budget.
• The report concludes that a detailed analysis of FAA costs and cost allocation is necessary to evaluate alternative funding options effectively.
• The report's findings and recommendations are intended for congressional review and consideration in the context of FAA reauthorization.
• The report includes a list of key contributors and contact points for further inquiries.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Mexican government has been combating the rise of criminal groups since the 1980s, with a significant focus on disrupting their operations under President Enrique Peña Nieto's administration, which prioritizes reducing criminal violence affecting civilians and businesses.
* Mexican Drug Trafficking Organizations (DTOs) engage in various criminal activities, including firearms trafficking, which is facilitated through straw purchases and unlicensed private sales in the U.S., often using the same routes as drug and cash smuggling.
* The U.S. and Mexican governments are collaborating to address DTO activities, including firearms trafficking, with the Mérida Initiative providing financial assistance to Mexico for security and justice sector capacity building.
* The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) are the primary U.S. agencies combating firearms trafficking, with ATF tracing firearms and ICE enforcing export laws and targeting illegal movements of firearms and other contraband.
* ATF and ICE have faced challenges in coordination and information sharing, but have improved collaboration through an interagency memorandum of understanding (MOU) and joint training exercises.
* The Strategy's indicator for tracking progress in stemming firearms trafficking to Mexico does not adequately measure implementation, and ONDCP has not reported on the strategic objective in 2011 or 2013.
* Recommendations include establishing a mechanism to monitor the MOU's implementation and developing a comprehensive set of indicators to evaluate progress in combating firearms trafficking.
* Fieldwork and interviews with U.S. and Mexican officials confirm the importance of cooperation in addressing firearms trafficking, despite challenges such as corruption and frequent turnover in Mexican law enforcement.
* The Strategy's supporting actions and associated activities should be considered alongside the indicator to provide a full picture of progress in combating arms trafficking.
</summary>

<summary>
• The U.S. Postal Service, with about 765,000 career employees in 1997, had a workforce structure with cluster-level employees making up 96 percent of the workforce, focusing on the diversity of the EAS workforce for review.
• The EAS workforce, which includes management-level positions, had 80,238 positions, representing 10 percent of total Service employees, with women and minorities facing challenges in advancing to higher positions.
• The Postal Service's Diversity Development Department was created to support recruitment, retention, and upward mobility of women and minorities, and the Service's 1999 Annual Performance Plan included achieving a diverse workforce as a goal.
• Aguirre International conducted a 6-month study on workforce diversity, which found that while the Service was a leader in meeting affirmative action goals, women and minorities were underrepresented in higher EAS positions, suggesting a potential glass ceiling.
• The Postal Service developed 23 initiatives in response to the Aguirre report, with varying degrees of completion, and is working on establishing specific targets and measures to track progress toward diversity goals.
• The Postal Service lacks reliable data on the flow of applicants through its promotion processes, which hinders the identification of barriers to the promotion of women and minorities.
• The Postal Service is advised to ensure the capture and use of EEO group data in the AFTS to improve its diversity program and identify any barriers to promotions to high-level EAS positions.
• The Postal Service's diversity initiatives and efforts to address the Aguirre report's recommendations are ongoing, with some initiatives completed and others still in progress.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) established the Superfund program for cleaning up severely contaminated hazardous waste sites, with Congress considering reauthorization.
* As of December 1996, 1,210 sites were on the National Priorities List (NPL), with EPA selecting incineration as a remedy for 43 of these sites.
* Three incinerators were operating at Superfund sites, with plans for four more, using controlled burning to convert contaminants into ash and gases.
* EPA ensures safe operation through site-specific standards, safety features, emissions monitoring, and 24-hour oversight, adhering to RCRA standards for hazardous waste incinerators.
* EPA's oversight includes continuous emissions monitoring, detailed laboratory analyses, and on-site inspections by Corps of Engineers or state officials.
* EPA has not fully implemented two methods to promote safe operation: periodic inspections by RCRA hazardous waste incinerator inspectors and systematic sharing of lessons learned from incineration projects.
* Residents near Superfund incinerators seek additional assurance of safe operation, which EPA has not fully provided.
* Recommendations include implementing guidance for RCRA hazardous waste incinerator inspectors to evaluate Superfund incinerators, documenting lessons learned, and sharing this information systematically.
* The report was reviewed by EPA officials, who agreed with the facts and conclusions but questioned the benefits of extensive documentation given the decreasing use of incineration.
* The report includes technical and editorial comments from EPA, which were incorporated as appropriate.
* The GAO conducted site visits and interviews to examine EPA's oversight of incinerators at Superfund sites and obtained various documents and data for analysis.
* The report aims to provide recommendations for improving EPA's oversight and public assurance regarding the safe operation of Superfund incinerators.
* The GAO provided copies of the draft report to EPA for review and comments, which were generally agreed upon, with some reservations about the extent of documentation.
* The report also

<summary>
* The Comanche program, established in 1983, aimed to replace the Army's light helicopter fleet with a low-cost, advanced technology helicopter for armed reconnaissance and attack missions.
* The Secretary of Defense's 1994 restructuring reduced funding and extended the development phase, deferring production decisions and increasing program risks.
* The Army's restructured program proposed acquiring six early operational capability aircraft and two prototypes, with operational testing to begin after production decisions, continuing concurrency risks.
* The Comanche program has seen significant cost increases and schedule delays, with the unit acquisition cost rising by 185% from 1985 to 1995, and development extending by about 3 years.
* The Comanche's software development is complex, with over 1.4 million lines of code, and integration issues due to different versions of the Ada compilation system used by developers.
* Maintainability goals for the Comanche are at risk due to high turnover of software engineers and delays in meeting requirements for direct maintenance man-hours per flight hour, mean time to repair, and fault isolation.
* The Comanche's weight has increased, affecting its vertical rate of climb performance, and the program's concurrency risks are heightened by the delayed start of operational testing.
* The report recommends that the Secretary of Defense require the Army to complete operational testing before committing funds to production, and that the program be reviewed at Milestone II before proceeding to the engineering and manufacturing development phase.
* The report has been revised to reflect concerns about the risks associated with the restructured Comanche program, particularly regarding concurrency and the achievement of performance and mission requirements.
* The GAO's comments on the DOD's letter and the report's findings are included in the appendices.
* The report was prepared under the direction of Thomas J. Schulz, Associate Director, Systems Development and Production Issues, and major contributors are listed in appendix II.
* The GAO's analysis of cost changes, software development, maintainability, and weight growth issues was conducted through interviews and document reviews.
* The report is available for purchase

<summary>
* The Military Health System (MHS) by DOD has a dual mission of readiness and benefits, providing medical services to armed forces and eligible beneficiaries.
* The Assistant Secretary of Defense (Health Affairs) oversees the execution of DOD's health care mission, with TRICARE operating civilian health care providers.
* Plans to renovate LRMC and the 86th MDG clinic were approved in 2008, with initial plans including inpatient tower renovation, construction of additional facilities, and demolition of older structures.
* A cost-benefit analysis in 2009 led to the decision to consolidate LRMC and 86th MDG into a single facility near Ramstein Air Base, with Army operation and Air Force clinical services.
* DOD's guidance for military health facility planning requires documentation of beneficiary population, staffing, and workload data, which informs facility size and cost estimates.
* The replacement medical center is designed for peacetime operations with the flexibility to expand for contingency operations, with a focus on minimizing impact from troop reductions in Europe.
* The facility will serve as the only tertiary-level referral hospital for EUCOM, Central Command, and Africa Command, with unique catchment area considerations.
* DOD officials used historical patient migration and contingency operation data to define catchment areas and project health care requirements.
* Sensitivity analysis indicated the planned facility capacities would be resilient to significant population changes.
* DOD's planning documentation contained inconsistencies, gaps, and calculation errors, raising concerns about the facility's adequacy for the expected beneficiary population.
* DOD's cost estimating process met best practices but lacked detailed documentation, making it difficult to assess the facility's cost-effectiveness and sizing.
* DOD has not fully assessed the impact of recent posture changes on facility requirements and cost estimates.
* GAO recommends that the Secretary of Defense direct the Assistant Secretary of Defense (Health Affairs) to provide clear documentation on facility requirements and revise the cost estimate to reflect potential posture changes.
* DOD has agreed with GAO's recommendations and is reassessing the

<summary>
• ICE estimates the unauthorized alien population in the U.S. to be around 12 million, with a significant increase in removals over the years.
• ICE's Office of Immigration Statistics reports a 24% growth in removable aliens from 2000 to 2005, with over 100 violations of immigration law as potential removal bases.
• ICE officers exercise discretion in the apprehension and removal process, particularly for non-targeted aliens with humanitarian issues, but this discretion is limited for investigation targets.
• The removal process involves six phases, with the initial phases involving the most discretion, allowing for alternate removal initiation methods.
• ICE attorneys and officers have limited discretion during removal proceedings and final removal, with clear policies and statutory requirements guiding their actions.
• Officers can exercise discretion in the charging phase by granting voluntary departure, considering factors like humanitarian concerns and ICE priorities.
• ICE's guidance on discretion is not comprehensive, especially for humanitarian issues and non-targeted aliens, and lacks updates to reflect expanded enforcement efforts.
• ICE has updated some training to support decision-making, but more comprehensive guidance is needed to fully support officers in exercising discretion.
• ICE's internal controls for monitoring discretion use are limited, relying on supervisory reviews and an inspection program without specific mechanisms for analyzing discretion use trends.
• ICE's data systems do not track detailed discretionary decisions, hindering trend analysis and identification of best practices or corrective actions.
• Recommendations include developing time frames for updating policies, a mechanism for consistent legal updates, and a reporting mechanism for analyzing discretion use trends.
• DHS agrees with recommendations and plans to address them, including reevaluating policies, developing best practices for legal updates, and initiating an evaluation for a reporting mechanism.
• The report's findings and recommendations are available to congressional committees, the Secretary of Homeland Security, and other interested parties.
• The review involved interviews and document reviews at ICE headquarters and field offices,

* TSA has made significant progress in enhancing screener training and performance monitoring since assuming responsibility for airport screening operations, but challenges remain in delivering ongoing training and ensuring compliance with training requirements.
* TSA's efforts to measure and improve screener performance have primarily focused on passenger screening, with limited data on checked baggage screening performance.
* TSA has implemented several training improvements, including a dual-function screener training program, an Online Learning Center, and recurrent training modules, but has faced difficulties in providing access to recurrent training due to staffing shortages and lack of high-speed Internet/intranet connectivity at some airports.
* TSA has not yet established performance targets for individual components of its screening performance indexes, making it difficult to assess and prioritize improvement efforts effectively.

<summary>
• Ground ambulance services are provided by various organizations with different structures, staffing, and funding, offering both BLS and ALS services.
• Medicare payments for ambulance services consist of a service-level payment and a mileage payment, with providers being for-profit, nonprofit, or government-based, and relying on various revenue sources.
• Providers' costs per transport in 2010 varied widely, influenced by factors such as transport volume, Medicare transport intensity, and community tax support.
• Personnel costs were the largest expense for providers, and the variability in costs did not significantly differ between service areas after controlling for other provider characteristics.
• The median Medicare margin for providers in 2010 was about 2%, but it decreased to negative 1% when add-on payments were removed.
• Ambulance transports for Medicare beneficiaries increased by 33% from 2004 to 2010, with the largest increase in super-rural areas, primarily due to BLS nonemergency transports.
• Increased Medicare billing by local governments and the introduction of the national fee schedule contributed to increased Medicare payments and utilization.
• The Medicare Payment Advisory Commission found an association between increased resources and increased costs in the ambulance industry, but causality was not established in this study.
• Providers' use of volunteer staff did not significantly contribute to differences in total costs, potentially due to small sample size and the proportion of providers using volunteers.
• Medicare payments for ground ambulance providers are lower than the calculated values for 2010 due to policy changes and increased costs of fuel since 2010.
• The report was sent to congressional committees and the CMS Administrator, and the GAO website made it available for free.
• The GAO conducted a survey and analyzed Medicare claims data to assess ambulance providers' costs, revenues, and characteristics, finding wide variation in costs and Medicare margins.
• The report's findings were generally agreed upon by AAA representatives, with some methodological questions clarified in the report.
• The GAO's work was conducted from

* The IRS operates a network of 10,000 customer service representatives across 25 call sites, managing call routing and staffing to optimize service. The Operations Center forecasts call demand and develops staffing requirements, but IRS lacks a long-term service-level goal, leading to inconsistent planning and performance. IRS's approach to staffing and resource allocation is inconsistent with federal guidance and industry practices, which emphasize customer needs and strategic planning. Challenges in recruiting, training, retaining, and scheduling staff, along with inadequate systems for assessing competency gaps and monitoring attrition, hinder IRS's ability to effectively manage its human capital and provide consistent telephone service. Recommendations include establishing long-term service goals, developing competency assessment systems, improving attrition monitoring, and evaluating human capital practices' impact on service goals.

<summary>
• Before 1996, Medicare program integrity activities were part of the general administrative budget, leading to funding constraints and reduced audit capabilities; HIPAA established the Medicare Integrity Program (MIP) in 1997, providing dedicated funding for program integrity activities, which increased from $430 million in 1997 to $720 million in 2003, and total MIP expenditures rose by about 63 percent from 1997 to 2005.
• CMS allocates MIP funds to support contractors' program integrity efforts, with provider education receiving the largest percentage increase in funds, while audit and medical review received the largest amount of funds overall; CMS officials have not routinely collected information to evaluate the comparative effectiveness of MIP activities, and the agency's approach to fund allocation does not always consider contractor vulnerabilities or the effectiveness of activities.
• CMS is developing new measures to evaluate the effectiveness of MIP activities, including a method of allocating funds based on effectiveness, workload, and risk; CMS also plans to use MIP funds as award payments to encourage superior performance among contractors.
• Medicare contracting reform will affect MIP funding allocations due to changes in contractors' responsibilities, potential operational efficiencies, and the reallocation of funds among MACs; CMS intends to use additional MIP funds for Part D program integrity efforts and to support the transition to MACs.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Office of the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Logistics & Materiel Readiness, led by the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, Technology and Logistics, oversees the development of DOD supply chain policies and the management of critical assets, including SRC I ammunition, with the Army playing a key role in procurement and storage.
• The Army depots manage SRC I ammunition and conduct semiannual physical inventories, while other military services have entities responsible for SRC I ammunition accountability, inventory, and transportation.
• As of April 30, 2015, the Army, Navy, Marine Corps, and Air Force collectively had approximately 226,000 SRC I missiles and rockets in the continental United States, with USTRANSCOM managing transportation of SRC I ammunition.
• DODM 5100.76 mandates continuous oversight and physical inventories of SRC I ammunition by serial number, with higher protection and security requirements for SRC I compared to other conventional ammunition.
• Automated information systems across the military services maintain accountability and visibility of SRC I ammunition, but there are gaps in service-level guidance and procedures, particularly with the Air Force not tracking SRC I by serial number and the Army not tracking in-transit items.
• The DOD is evaluating systems like NLAC to serve as a DOD-wide authoritative source of data for conventional ammunition, including SRC I, to improve asset visibility.
• Reports from 1994 and 1997 highlighted issues with serial number control and inventory accountability, leading to policy revisions and recommendations for better management practices.
• The DOD has concurred with recommendations to improve management and accountability of SRC I ammunition, including updating performance work statements and implementing internal controls for data accuracy and completeness.
• The military services have maintained accountability of SRC I ammunition at sampled locations, but gaps exist in service-level guidance and procedures, especially regarding in-transit accountability and receipting time frames.
• The DOD emphasizes the need for continuous oversight to protect sensitive conventional arms, ammunition, and explos

<summary>
• The federal government, particularly the Social Security Administration (SSA), is a major producer, collector, and user of personal information, with SSA responsible for issuing Social Security Numbers (SSNs) and maintaining wage and earnings information for various income support programs.
• SSA's disclosure policy, designed to protect individual privacy, is more restrictive than the Privacy Act and most federal agencies, with specific conditions under which personal information can be disclosed to law enforcement.
• SSA's policy includes considerations such as the nature of the alleged criminal activity, the information requested, and the requesting agency before disclosure, and requires a written request signed by an official.
• SSA's disclosure policy is reinforced by statutes like the Privacy Act of 1974, which regulates the collection, maintenance, use, and disclosure of personal information by federal agencies, and the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) and Government in the Sunshine Act, which require agencies to justify withholding information.
• SSA's policy allows disclosure of information without consent under 12 exceptions, including law enforcement requests, provided they meet certain criteria and are in writing, signed by the agency head, and specify the information and activity involved.
• SSA's Office of the Inspector General (OIG) can disclose information under a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with law enforcement, but only for specific cases involving fraud or misuse of SSNs, and must follow SSA's disclosure policy and the Privacy Act.
• SSA's disclosure policy is more restrictive than that of the IRS and Census Bureau, which have statutory requirements for disclosure.
• SSA's policy aims to balance the need for privacy protection with the necessity of sharing information for law enforcement purposes, and is implemented through regulations, training, and regional privacy coordinators.
• SSA's disclosure policy is complex and sometimes leads to inconsistent application, with some field office staff and law enforcement officials finding it confusing and frustrating.
• SSA's Commissioner can invoke ad hoc authority for specific cases to disclose information, but this is done infrequently and with careful consideration.
• SSA's dis

* Ginnie Mae, a unit of HUD, plays a key role in the secondary mortgage market by guaranteeing payments on MBS backed by government-insured or guaranteed loans, thus expanding affordable housing opportunities. Its products include Ginnie Mae I, II, and Multiclass Securities, with varying degrees of homogeneity and risk profiles.
* Ginnie Mae's market share in the MBS market has declined over the past 20 years due to the growth of the conventional mortgage market and the securitization of conventional mortgages, despite its consistent guarantee of over 90% of FHA and VA loans.
* Challenges for Ginnie Mae include adapting to market changes, ensuring accurate loan data, managing its small staff and reliance on contractors, and maintaining sufficient commitment authority to meet the needs of its programs without disrupting the market.
* Ginnie Mae has taken steps to address these challenges, such as expanding its product offerings, soliciting stakeholder feedback, and improving loan data disclosures, but faces potential competition from other secondary market entities and legislative changes affecting its programs.

<summary>
* The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) of 1976, with amendments in 1984, sets national policy for the safe management of hazardous waste to protect human health and the environment, including during cleanups.
* EPA has established criteria for identifying hazardous waste, which applies to waste from current and past operations, including remediation waste.
* Legislative proposals have been introduced to exempt certain remediation waste from RCRA requirements, giving states more authority to manage it.
* EPA has proposed and later withdrew a comprehensive rule to manage remediation waste, citing disagreements on key issues.
* EPA plans to issue regulations covering four specific elements affecting remediation waste, after stakeholder consultations and interviews.
* Cleanup managers identify land disposal restrictions, minimum technological requirements, and permit requirements as the three most significant RCRA requirements that add cost and time to cleanups.
* These requirements can lead to the selection of less aggressive remedies, as parties aim to meet or avoid stringent standards.
* Exempting low-risk contaminated media from land disposal restrictions could significantly reduce cleanup costs without compromising health or environmental protection.
* The "contained-in" policy allows for case-by-case exclusion of media from RCRA regulation, but its application has been inconsistent nationwide.
* The CAMU rule allows for on-site treatment, storage, or disposal of waste without RCRA's land disposal restrictions, but its legal status is uncertain.
* Stakeholders have varied experiences with EPA's policy and regulatory alternatives, with some finding them burdensome or inefficient.
* EPA's proposed regulatory reforms have been met with legal challenges and disagreements over their scope and implementation.
* EPA recommends steps to ensure consistent application of existing policies and alternatives to manage remediation waste under RCRA until comprehensive legislative reform is achieved.
* The report suggests that comprehensive reform of RCRA's requirements for remediation waste management is best addressed through legislative action.
* The report was developed following a series of stakeholder meetings and interviews, and it includes technical revisions and clarifications suggested by EPA

* Congress authorized the State's ATA program in 1983 to enhance antiterrorism skills, strengthen bilateral ties, and promote human rights through training and equipment. ATA's funding has fluctuated but increased since 2002, with the top 10 recipients receiving the majority of funds. The Coordinator for Counterterrorism (S/CT) and the Bureau of Diplomatic Security's Terrorism and Counterterrorism (DS/T/ATA) are responsible for overseeing ATA, but their assessments and planning processes have been inconsistent and not always aligned with U.S. policy goals. State has made some progress in defining goals and measures for ATA, but lacks clear sustainability measures and has not complied with reporting requirements to Congress since 1996. State has agreed to improve its ATA program guidance and assessments, but has not addressed the congressional mandate for annual reporting on counterterrorism assistance.

• The Internet, initially a U.S. government-sponsored research project, has become integral to global commerce and essential services, with its domain name system (DNS) ensuring the uniqueness of e-mail and website addresses. The DNS relies on 13 root servers for translating domain names into Internet addresses, with the U.S. government supporting its development and management for nearly a decade. A 1997 presidential directive led to the Department of Commerce's initiative to transition DNS management to the private sector, culminating in the "White Paper" and a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with ICANN. Despite ICANN's progress in increasing competition among registrars, challenges remain in enhancing the stability, security, and representation of the Internet community, as well as formalizing relationships with root server operators and country-code domain operators. ICANN's president called for fundamental reform in February 2002, citing slow progress and the need for a new structure. The Department of Commerce's oversight has been informal, with limited public comment on ICANN's progress, and the future of the MOU and ICANN's role in managing the DNS remains uncertain as the September 2002 expiration date approaches.

• Treasury extended TARP to address ongoing economic weaknesses and uncertainties, focusing on housing market stabilization and small business lending, while considering the need for flexibility to respond to potential financial instability.
• Treasury's decision-making process involved coordination with Federal Reserve and FDIC, and was informed by quantitative indicators and public documents, though challenges remain in setting clear objectives and exiting programs effectively.

<summary>
* DOD has agreed to reverse $592 million of illegal and improper adjustments, with the remaining $23 million under review, and has provided additional documentation for $8 million of proper adjustments.
* The reversal process has uncovered further accounting issues, with detailed reviews required for the remaining adjustments, involving 30 contracts with over $457 million in reversals.
* The Defense Finance and Accounting Service (DFAS) estimates it will take over 21,000 hours to correct the accounting for the 30 contracts with reversals, and about 2,300 hours for a specific contract with $210 million in unnecessary adjustments.
* Additional illegal adjustments identified in fiscal year 2001 totaling $172 million have been agreed to be reversed, with the remaining $119 million for documented corrections of past errors.
* DOD has implemented controls to prevent illegal adjustments, resulting in an 80% reduction in closed account adjustments during the first 6 months of fiscal year 2002, but long-term problems persist due to complex contracts and payment allocation terms.
* The GAO recommends continued oversight and monitoring of DOD's efforts to correct past adjustments and prevent future ones, with a focus on simplifying accounting and contract payment terms.
* The GAO suggests that Congress consider options to prohibit adjustments to closed accounts or amend the account closing law to prevent such adjustments, weighing the benefits of finality against potential payment and funding limitations.
* DOD has made significant improvements to its controls and is working to correct the identified adjustments, with a plan to complete all reaudits and corrections by September 2004.
* The GAO will continue to monitor DOD's progress and provide updates to Congress and other stakeholders.
* Major contributors to the report include Bertram J. Berlin, Francine M. Delvecchio, Stephen P. Donahue, Dennis B. Fauber, Jeffrey A. Jacobson, Keith E. McDaniel, and Harold P. Santarelli.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) outlines the goal of an income tax audit as determining correct taxable income and tax liability, emphasizing quality audits for both the audited taxpayer and all taxpayers.
* The IRS employs nine audit standards, evolving since the 1960s, to define audit quality, covering scope, techniques, technical conclusions, reports, time management, and workpaper preparation.
* Audit workpapers are crucial for planning, documenting procedures, supporting technical conclusions, and forming the basis for the auditor's report to the taxpayer.
* IRS' Examination Quality Measurement System (EQMS) collects information on audit processes, quality, and improvements, but IRS has historically found issues with workpaper quality.
* A review of IRS audit workpapers from 1996-1997 revealed that auditors often did not meet the workpaper standard requirements, with only 6% of workpapers showing documentation of group manager review during the audit.
* IRS is drafting changes to the IRM to require documentation of managerial involvement in the audit process, including supervisory review of workpapers.
* The IRS Commissioner agreed to revisions to the IRM instructions to implement recommendations by October 1998, with concerns about the sufficiency of managerial practices and the need for documentation of supervisory review.
* The report suggests that the IRS Commissioner should mandate audit supervisors to document their review of workpapers to ensure quality control over audits and workpapers.
* The report includes technical comments from IRS officials and acknowledges other managerial practices providing oversight, but emphasizes the need for documented supervisory review.
* Major contributors to the report are listed in an appendix, and copies can be requested from the contact provided.
* The report was issued by the Office of Compliance Specialization within the IRS Examination Division.
</summary>

<summary>
* The U.S. federal government has managed Indian tribal trust funds since 1820, with significant reforms and management responsibilities outlined in the General Allotment Act of 1887 and the Indian Reorganization Act of 1934.
* The Department of the Interior's Office of the Special Trustee (OST) oversees these funds, including accounting, investment, and record-keeping for fractionated land interests.
* OST has grown in budget and staff since 1997, with increased responsibilities and funding for various Indian-related activities.
* OST has implemented several key trust fund management reforms, including the Trust Funds Accounting System (TFAS) and a centralized Trust Beneficiary Call Center, but has not set a timetable for completing all reforms or for its potential termination.
* OST has contracted with various firms for trust reform activities, with a significant portion of its budget allocated to contracting.
* The Special Trustee has not provided a timetable for completing trust reforms or a termination date for OST, despite the 1994 Act's sunset provision.
* OST's workforce plan for post-reform operations is unclear, and there may be opportunities to reduce expenditures and staffing levels.
* Interior has agreed to provide a timetable for completing trust reforms and a plan for future operations, including potential termination of OST.
* The Special Trustee has received performance awards and retention allowances, with the Principal Deputy Special Trustee receiving a retention allowance due to her historical knowledge and managerial ability.
* OST's SES managers have received numerous major awards, with the average award amount for OST's SES managers generally lower than that of other Interior bureaus and federal agencies.
* Interior's ERB approved all major awards provided to OST's SES managers.
* OST's contracting practices have been under scrutiny for potential preferential treatment, leading to mandatory ethics training for senior OST employees.
* OST's progress in implementing trust reforms has been mixed, with some reforms completed and others still pending.
* The Special Trustee

<summary>
* FDA and USDA are responsible for ensuring the safety of various food products, with FDA overseeing most foods and FSIS focusing on meat, poultry, and certain egg products.
* Both agencies use the HACCP system to identify and minimize risks of contamination in food processing facilities.
* FDA and FSIS conduct regular inspections, with states also conducting yearly inspections of food-processing facilities.
* Post-9/11, the federal government increased efforts to protect the food supply from deliberate contamination, providing emergency funding to FDA and FSIS for security measures and counter-bioterrorism activities.
* FDA and USDA have taken actions to enhance food security, including hiring new personnel, conducting exercises, and developing guidelines, but lack the authority to mandate security measures or collect information on their implementation.
* The industry is voluntarily implementing security measures, and there is a call for federal agencies to study their statutes and identify additional authorities needed for food-processing facility security.
</summary>

<summary>
* In 1998, VA and DOD initiated the GCPR project to develop an electronic interface for sharing patient health information, but faced challenges due to lack of clear leadership and planning.
* Recommendations in 2001 and 2002 included designating a lead entity, creating comprehensive plans, and revising project goals to align with current strategies.
* The project evolved into the FHIE program, which completed its first phase in 2002, allowing one-way data transfer from DOD to VA, and was fully operational by 2004, contributing significantly to care and disability claims adjudication.
* The FHIE framework was also used to transfer pre- and postdeployment health assessment data, with VA receiving about 400,000 records.
* The HealthePeople (Federal) initiative aimed for a two-way exchange of health information between DOD and VA, requiring the development of a common health information architecture and the CHDR interface.
* Despite progress, the CHDR program faced management weaknesses, leading to recommendations for a well-defined architecture, a project management lead entity, and a comprehensive project management plan.
* VA and DOD have implemented demonstration projects, BHIE and LDSI, to improve health information exchange, with BHIE providing near-real-time data exchange and LDSI enhancing laboratory test result sharing.
* The CHDR initiative has made progress, but faces challenges in project management, data completeness, and interoperability with systems outside CHCS.
* The departments have taken steps to improve project management and collaboration, but still face significant challenges to achieve their long-term goals of a comprehensive, two-way exchange of health information.
* The success of the CHDR initiative is crucial for the future sharing of computable health data between VA's Health Data Repository and DOD's Clinical Data Repository.
* VA and DOD continue to work on improving the management and execution of the CHDR program to meet their long-term objectives.
* The testimony includes contributions from various individuals and is a work of the U.S. government, available for reproduction and distribution without further permission

<summary>
• Bankruptcy can be voluntary or involuntary, with proceedings under Chapters 7 and 11 allowing for liquidation or reorganization, respectively, with the debtor often remaining in control of assets.
• The U.S. bankruptcy system involves multiple federal entities, including bankruptcy courts, the Judicial Conference, AOUSC, the Federal Judicial Center, and the U.S. Trustee Program, which oversee and support the administration of bankruptcy cases.
• Large financial companies filing for bankruptcy typically use Chapter 11, with the debtor having exclusive rights to file a reorganization plan within 120 days, which must be approved by the court.
• Outcomes of bankruptcy can include asset sales under Section 363, liquidation with court approval, or reorganization with new contractual rights and obligations.
• Adversary proceedings can be initiated for various reasons, including to recover property or subordinate claims.
• Regulators, while not explicitly named as parties of interest, frequently appear before the court in financial company bankruptcies, with the FDIC, CFTC, and SEC playing significant roles in different types of bankruptcies.
• The Dodd-Frank Act's Orderly Liquidation Authority (OLA) allows the FDIC to resolve large financial companies outside of bankruptcy, with the SPOE approach being a key component of this strategy.
• Chapter 15 of the Bankruptcy Code facilitates cross-border insolvency coordination, with over 450 cases filed since its adoption, primarily in the Southern District of New York and the District of Delaware.
• No changes have been made to Chapters 7, 11, or 15 of the Bankruptcy Code specifically for large financial companies since July 2013, but bills were introduced in the 113th Congress to address challenges associated with Chapter 11 reorganizations.
• The Taxpayer Protection and Responsible Resolution Act and the Financial Institution Bankruptcy Act of 2014 proposed changes to the bankruptcy process for large financial firms, including the creation of a bridge company and the designation of judges with expertise in financial

<summary>
* The electricity industry consists of generation, transmission, distribution, and system operations, with utilities owning and operating assets like plants and substations.
* System operators manage electricity flows using IT and network-based control systems, which have historically lacked technologies for monitoring electricity flow, integrated communications, and automated management.
* The smart grid vision aims to modernize the grid with IT systems, two-way communication, and automation to improve reliability, efficiency, and consumer information.
* Federal and state authorities regulate the industry, with FERC overseeing wholesale sales and transmission, and state commissions overseeing local distribution. NERC ensures bulk power system reliability and develops standards, which are voluntary unless enforced through other regulatory means.
* Cybersecurity threats to the electricity grid are evolving, with risks from both unintentional and intentional sources, including sophisticated attacks that could disrupt critical services.
* NERC, NIST, FERC, and the Department of Homeland Security have developed standards and guidelines to protect the grid, but challenges remain in implementation, compliance monitoring, and clarifying regulatory responsibilities.
* The industry lacks comprehensive cybersecurity programs, built-in security features in smart grid systems, effective information sharing mechanisms, and metrics for evaluating cybersecurity solutions.
* FERC has taken steps to address cybersecurity challenges, including revising CIP standards and establishing an Office of Energy Infrastructure Security, but monitoring the implementation of voluntary standards is still needed.
* The electricity industry's increasing reliance on IT and the evolving nature of cyber threats necessitate continued attention to mitigate risks to the grid.
* Key stakeholders, including NERC, FERC, NIST, DHS, and the Department of Energy, play roles in protecting the sector against cyber threats, but challenges in standard implementation and regulatory clarity persist.
* The industry needs to adopt a comprehensive approach to cybersecurity, ensure smart grid systems have built-in security features, effectively share cybersecurity information, and develop metrics for evaluating cybersecurity solutions.
* The smart grid's potential benefits include improved reliability, reduced electricity rates, efficient use of

* 18F and USDS have provided a variety of development and consulting services to federal agencies, with most surveyed agency project managers satisfied with the services received.
* Both organizations have developed outcome-oriented goals and procedures for prioritizing projects, but not all goals and measures are fully outcome-oriented or have established performance targets.
* 18F has not fully assessed actual results against its performance measures, and USDS has not fully implemented important program management practices, making it difficult to hold them accountable for results.
* USDS policy does not clearly define the relationship between CIOs and digital service teams, potentially hindering CIOs' ability to carry out their responsibilities for IT management of projects undertaken by these teams.

<summary>
• Federal workforce skills gaps pose a high risk to national interests, with potential retirements exacerbating the issue.
• Agencies face skills gaps due to insufficient numbers, inappropriate skills, and fiscal pressures.
• Over 34% of federal employees by 2015's end are eligible to retire by 2020, with some agencies like HUD facing high eligibility levels.
• Strategic monitoring and management of turnover are crucial to prevent knowledge and leadership gaps.
• Various tools exist to address talent needs, but challenges persist in classification, recruiting, pay systems, performance management, and employee engagement.
• The GS system is outdated, and pay adjustments are not always performance-based.
• Federal jobs now require more advanced skills and degrees than private sector jobs, indicating a need for a more market-based and performance-oriented pay system.
• Agency leaders must set an example that human capital is linked to performance, not just a transactional function.
• OPM has taken steps like finalizing the Human Capital Framework, but needs to track and prioritize occupations for updates and ensure correct classification.
• Effective performance management is key to retaining top talent and aligning individual performance with organizational success.
• Agencies should promote qualified individuals into supervisory roles and ensure new supervisors are trained in performance management.
• VA concurred with recommendations to improve human resource capacity and performance management systems.
• Agencies must leverage existing tools and flexibilities to improve personnel management and hold themselves accountable.
• The federal compensation system should attract, motivate, and retain a high-performing workforce within budgetary constraints.
• GAO will continue to assess progress in improving human capital infrastructure to support agency planning and programmatic functions.

• Contact points for GAO's Offices of Congressional Relations and Public Affairs are provided at the end of the statement.
